title: 109_hr4274
content: The Act titled "Preservation of Defined Benefit Plans Act of 2005" includes rules regarding the reduction of accrued benefits due to reaching a certain age. The "Preservation of Defined Benefit Plans Act of 2005" includes an amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 related to the reduction of accrued benefits upon reaching a certain age. The account for the participant shall not be age discriminatory if their accrued benefit under the plan is equal to or greater than that of any similarly situated younger individual. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to prevent age discrimination in defined benefit plans where the accrued benefit is expressed as an account balance for the participant. The plan must ensure that the participant's benefit is equal to or greater than that of any similarly situated younger individual. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to prevent age discrimination in defined benefit plans by ensuring that a participant's accrued benefit is equal to or greater than that of any similarly situated younger individual. The amendments apply to plan years before, on, or after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. Determinations of accrued benefit as balance of benefit account. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding minimum vesting standards for defined benefit plans. A plan where the accrued benefit is expressed as an account balance will not fail to meet requirements solely based on the amount available for distribution. The Secretary may establish regulations for calculating a market rate of return and crediting interest to accounts in defined benefit plans. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to allow defined benefit plans with accrued benefits expressed as account balances to meet requirements for distribution, regardless of the actual amount available, as long as the interest rate meets specified criteria. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to allow defined benefit plans with accrued benefits expressed as account balances to meet distribution requirements if the present value does not exceed a market rate of return. The Secretary of the Treasury may establish rules for calculating the market rate of return and crediting interest. These amendments apply to plan years starting after the enactment of the Act. AGE DISCRIMINATION PROTECTIONS FOR PENSION PLAN PARTICIPANTS FROM CASH BALANCE CONVERSIONS. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces Age Discrimination Safe Harbor Rules for Certain Plan Conversions, ensuring that the opening account balance of each participant in a defined benefit plan is at least equal to the present value of their retirement benefit at age 65 before the effective date of the plan amendment. The term `applicable plan amendment' refers to converting a defined benefit plan to one where the accrued benefit is expressed as a different amount. Special transition rules apply to plan amendments adopted between January 1, 1997, and November 9, 2005. The enactment states that participants separated before November 9, 2005, are not considered until 3 years after the enactment date. An amendment to a defined benefit plan must ensure that each participant's account balance equals their retirement benefit at age 65 before the amendment's effective date. The enactment specifies that applicable plan amendments converting defined benefit plans must ensure participant account balances equal their retirement benefits at age 65 before the effective date. This provision does not apply to amendments adopted between January 1, 1997, and November 9, 2005, until 2 years after enactment. Participants separated before November 9, 2005, are not considered until 3 years after the enactment date. The amendments made by this section shall take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act, and amendments adopted between January 1, 1997, and November 9, 2005, need not be considered until 3 years after enactment. SEC. 5. WEAR AWAY PROTECTIONS IN PENSION PLAN CASH BALANCE CONVERSIONS. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 adds a new subsection regarding the treatment of plan amendments wearing away accrued benefits in defined benefit plans. The plan amendment must ensure that the participant's accrued benefit is not less than a certain sum after the adoption of the amendment. The plan amendment must protect the participant's accrued benefit by combining benefits before and after the effective date, with an option for employers to choose a method for participants with at least 10 years of service. The plan amendment allows participants within 5 years of retirement eligibility to maintain their current rate of benefit accrual or choose benefits under the new plan terms upon retirement. The plan allows participants close to retirement to keep their current benefits or opt for new plan terms upon retirement, ensuring their benefits do not decrease for at least 5 years after the plan amendment. The plan ensures that participants close to retirement can maintain their current benefits or choose new plan terms, guaranteeing that their benefits will not decrease for at least 5 years after the plan amendment. An applicable plan amendment for a defined benefit plan must ensure that the accrued benefits of participants do not decrease after the adoption of the amendment. An applicable plan amendment for a defined benefit plan must ensure that participants' accrued benefits do not decrease. The plan must provide notice of the amendment to participants with at least 10 years of service and nearing retirement eligibility. The plan amendment must ensure that participants' accrued benefits do not decrease. Participants may choose to receive benefits based on the plan terms at retirement or before the plan amendment. Benefits after the amendment must not be less than the greatest benefits the participant would have received. The plan amendment must maintain participants' accrued benefits for at least the first 5 years. Accrued benefits include early retirement benefits or subsidies for participants who meet the conditions before or after the plan amendment. The amendments made by this section apply to any plan amendment adopted after the enactment of this Act.
